source.raw_text:
The Arched Hang is a calisthenics movement that trains scapular control, upper back strength (lats, rhomboids, traps), posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings), and thoracic mobility, while stretching abs and hip flexors, improving posture, and building grip strength, used to prep for pull-ups and develop a strong, active hanging position with an arched spine and chest up. [1, 2, 3]  
This video demonstrates how to perform the arched hang: 
Muscles Worked 

• Upper Back & Shoulders: Latissimus Dorsi (lats), Rhomboids, Trapezius (traps), Posterior Deltoids, Rotator Cuff. 
• Grip & Forearms: Hand/wrist flexors, forearms. 
• Core: Abdominals, obliques (for stability and opposition). 
• Posterior Chain: Glutes, hamstrings (for squeezing and extension). [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Start: Begin in a passive dead hang from a pull-up bar. 
2. Engage Scapulae: Pull your shoulder blades down and together (retraction and depression). 
3. Arch & Extend: Arch your upper back, pointing your chest up towards the bar, keeping elbows straight. 
4. Squeeze Glutes: Squeeze your glutes and keep legs extended behind you. 
5. Hold: Maintain this active, arched position to build strength and control. 
6. Return: Slowly release back to a passive hang. [1, 2, 3, 6]  

You can see the arched hang being performed in this video: 
Key Benefits & Purpose 

• Strengthens: Scapular control, straight-arm strength, grip, and entire posterior chain. 
• Improves: Thoracic spine mobility, posture, and overhead shoulder range. 
• Prepares For: Pull-ups, muscle-ups, and other pulling skills. [1, 2, 3]  

**Citations:**
